title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: partycoloR package extracts political party colors logos English Wikipedia party pages. useful political scientists data visualization practitioners want consistent, recognizable colors political parties charts graphs.

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: main function get_party_color() takes Wikipedia URLs returns party’s primary color hex code:
code: # Single party dem_url <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" get_party_color(dem_url) #> "#0015BC"  # Multiple parties urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_United_States" ) get_party_color(urls) #> "#0015BC" "#E81B23" "#17AA5C"

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: parties one official color. Use all_colors = TRUE get colors:
code: # German CDU has black and orange cdu_url <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_of_Germany" get_party_color(cdu_url, all_colors = TRUE) #> [[1]] #> [1] "#000000" "#FF6600"

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Use get_party_logo() get URL party’s logo image:
code: get_party_logo(dem_url) #> "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/..."

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: efficiency, use get_party_info() extract color logo single request:
code: get_party_info(urls) #> # A tibble: 3 x 3 #>   url                                                      color   logo_url #>   <chr>                                                    <chr>   <chr> #> 1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Unite... #0015BC https://... #> 2 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(Unite... #E81B23 https://... #> 3 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_Unit... #17AA5C https://...

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: functions designed work seamlessly dplyr::mutate():
code: parties <- tibble(   party = c("Democrats", "Republicans", "Greens"),   wiki_url = c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_United_States"   ) )  parties %>%   mutate(     color = get_party_color(wiki_url),     logo = get_party_logo(wiki_url)   )

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: using all_colors = TRUE, result list-column. Use purrr functions extract specific colors: Alternatively, unnest long format (one row per color):
code: library(purrr)  german_parties <- tibble(   party = c("CDU", "SPD"),   wiki_url = c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_of_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany"   ) )  # Extract all colors as a list-column, then extract individual colors german_parties %>%   mutate(     all_colors = get_party_color(wiki_url, all_colors = TRUE),     color_1 = map_chr(all_colors, pluck, 1, 1, .default = NA_character_),     color_2 = map_chr(all_colors, pluck, 1, 2, .default = NA_character_)   ) #> # A tibble: 2 x 5 #>   party wiki_url                              all_colors color_1 color_2 #>   <chr> <chr>                                 <list>     <chr>   <chr> #> 1 CDU   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris.. <list [1]> #000000 #FF6600 #> 2 SPD   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soci..  <list [1]> #E3000F NA german_parties %>%   mutate(all_colors = get_party_color(wiki_url, all_colors = TRUE)) %>%   tidyr::unnest_longer(all_colors) %>%   tidyr::unnest_longer(all_colors, values_to = "color") #> # A tibble: 3 x 3 #>   party wiki_url                                               color #>   <chr> <chr>                                                  <chr> #> 1 CDU   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic...  #000000 #> 2 CDU   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic...  #FF6600 #> 3 SPD   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Pa...  #E3000F

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: don’t Wikipedia URLs, can look parties name using Partyfacts database integration.

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
code: # Download the current Partyfacts Wikipedia dataset pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia() head(pf_data) #> # A tibble: 6 x 8 #>   country partyfacts_id url         name_short name  name_native year_founded #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>       <chr>      <chr> <chr>              <int> #> 1 AFG              6641 https://... NA         Afgh... NA                 1966 #> ...

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
code: # Search for a party by name lookup_party_url("SPD", country = "DEU") #> # A tibble: 1 x 8 #>   country partyfacts_id url                             name_short name #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>                           <chr>      <chr> #> 1 DEU              1375 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/... SPD      Social...  # Search across all countries lookup_party_url("Labour")

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Use get_party_color_by_name() combine lookup color extraction:
code: # Get SPD color directly by name get_party_color_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU") #> "#E3000F"  # If multiple parties match, returns a tibble with all matches get_party_color_by_name("Labour") #> # A tibble: 12 x 9 #>    country partyfacts_id url    name_short name  ... color #>    ...

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: ’s use party colors ggplot2 visualization:
code: library(ggplot2)  # Example data: German 2021 election results german_parties <- tibble(   party = c("SPD", "CDU/CSU", "Greens", "FDP", "AfD", "Left"),   vote_share = c(25.7, 24.1, 14.8, 11.5, 10.3, 4.9),   wiki_url = c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_of_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alliance_90/The_Greens",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Democratic_Party_(Germany)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_for_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Left_(Germany)"   ) )  # Get party colors german_parties <- german_parties %>%   mutate(color = get_party_color(wiki_url))  # Create bar chart with party colors ggplot(german_parties, aes(x = reorder(party, -vote_share), y = vote_share)) +   geom_col(fill = german_parties$color) +   labs(     title = "German Federal Election 2021",     x = NULL,     y = "Vote Share (%)"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: functions handle errors gracefully:
code: # Invalid URLs return NA get_party_color("https://not-wikipedia.com/page") #> NA  # Non-existent pages return NA get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonexistent_Party_12345") #> NA  # Mixed valid and invalid URLs urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   NA,   "invalid_url" ) get_party_color(urls) #> "#0015BC" NA NA

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Partyfacts data cached R session avoid repeated downloads:
code: # First call downloads the data pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia()  # Subsequent calls use the cache (faster) pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia()  # Clear the cache if needed clear_partycolor_cache()

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Batch requests: processing many parties, pass URLs get_party_color() rather calling loop. Cache Partyfacts data: ’ll multiple lookups, call get_partyfacts_wikipedia() pass result lookup_party_url(). Handle missing data: Always check NA values results, Wikipedia pages may color information may unexpected formatting. Wikipedia changes: scraping depends Wikipedia’s HTML structure. results seem wrong, Wikipedia page format may changed.

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Partyfacts - source party identifiers Wikipedia URLs ParlGov - Parliament government database Manifesto Project - Party manifestos positions

what: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
text: goal partycoloR extract color information Wikipedia articles political parties. Party colors playing crucial role visually identifying political parties. function wikipedia_party_color extracts party color code (HEX/HTML color codes / names) webscraped English Wikipedia political party pages. input argument needs list function generates data frame / tibble extracted color codes / names.

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
text: can install released version partycoloR GitHub :
code: devtools::install_github("lwarode/partycoloR")

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
text: input argument list political party articles (URL) English Wikipedia. function returns data frame / tibble party colors (HEX color HTML color code).
code: party_list <- list( "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" )  party_color_df <- wikipedia_party_color(party_list)  glimpse(party_color_df)

title: Clear the partycoloR cache — clear_partycolor_cache
text: Clears cached data (Partyfacts dataset) current R session.

title: Clear the partycoloR cache — clear_partycolor_cache
code: clear_partycolor_cache()

title: Clear the partycoloR cache — clear_partycolor_cache
text: Invisible NULL.

title: Clear the partycoloR cache — clear_partycolor_cache
code: clear_partycolor_cache()

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
text: Downloads party logo image URL saves file.

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
code: download_party_logo(logo_url, destfile, overwrite = FALSE)

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
text: logo_url character string logo URL ([get_party_logo()]). destfile Path image saved. overwrite Logical. `TRUE`, overwrite existing files.

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
text: Invisible `TRUE` successful, `FALSE` otherwise.

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ logo_url <- get_party_logo(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" ) download_party_logo(logo_url, "democratic_logo.png") } # }

what: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: Extracts primary party color (colors) political party's English Wikipedia page. function scrapes party infobox color information.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
code: get_party_color(url, all_colors = FALSE, normalize = TRUE)

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: url character vector Wikipedia URLs political party pages. all_colors Logical. `FALSE` (default), returns first/primary color. `TRUE`, returns colors list. normalize Logical. `TRUE` (default), attempts normalize color values uppercase hex codes. Named colors (e.g., "red") converted hex codes.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: `all_colors = FALSE`, character vector hex color codes   (NA failed extractions). `all_colors = TRUE`, list   character vectors containing colors URL.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: function works scraping Wikipedia infobox (vcard table) spans background-color style attributes. depends Wikipedia's current HTML structure may occasionally fail page structure changes. use `dplyr::mutate()`, function vectorized `url` argument. URL processed independently.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Single party get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)")  # Multiple parties urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" ) get_party_color(urls)  # Get all colors (some parties have multiple) get_party_color(urls, all_colors = TRUE)  # Use with dplyr library(dplyr) parties <- tibble(   party = c("Democrats", "Republicans"),   wiki_url = urls ) parties %>%   mutate(color = get_party_color(wiki_url)) } # }

what: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
text: convenience function combines party lookup color extraction. Searches party name, finds Wikipedia URL, extracts party color.

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
code: get_party_color_by_name(   party_name,   country = NULL,   all_colors = FALSE,   data = NULL )

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
text: party_name character string party name search . country Optional. ISO 3-letter country code filter results. all_colors Logical. `TRUE`, returns colors. Default `FALSE`. data Optional. Partyfacts dataset.

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
text: exactly one party found, returns color(s). multiple   parties match, returns tibble party info colors. Returns NA   party found.

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get color for German SPD get_party_color_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU")  # Search more broadly get_party_color_by_name("Labour", country = "GBR") } # }

what: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: Extracts party color(s) logo URL political party's English Wikipedia page single call.

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
code: get_party_info(url, all_colors = FALSE)

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: url character vector Wikipedia URLs political party pages. all_colors Logical. `FALSE` (default), returns primary color `color` column. `TRUE`, adds `all_colors` list-column.

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: tibble columns: `url`, `color` (primary color hex),   `logo_url`, optionally `all_colors` (list colors).

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: function combines [get_party_color()] [get_party_logo()] single call, efficient need pieces information fetches Wikipedia page .

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get info for multiple parties urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany" ) get_party_info(urls)  # Include all colors get_party_info(urls, all_colors = TRUE) } # }

what: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: Extracts party logo image URL political party's English Wikipedia page. function scrapes party infobox logo image.

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
code: get_party_logo(url)

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: url character vector Wikipedia URLs political party pages.

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: character vector logo image URLs (NA failed extractions   pages without logos).

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: function looks logo images Wikipedia infobox. returned URL typically Wikimedia Commons thumbnail URL. Note party pages may logos, logo may non-standard location. returned URLs point image files hosted Wikimedia servers. can used directly R graphics downloaded processing. use `dplyr::mutate()`, function vectorized `url` argument.

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Single party get_party_logo("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)")  # Multiple parties urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" ) get_party_logo(urls)  # Use with dplyr library(dplyr) parties <- tibble(   party = c("Democrats", "Republicans"),   wiki_url = urls ) parties %>%   mutate(logo_url = get_party_logo(wiki_url)) } # }

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: Downloads current Partyfacts Wikipedia dataset containing party names, countries, Wikipedia URLs thousands political parties worldwide.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
code: get_partyfacts_wikipedia(cache = TRUE)

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: cache Logical. `TRUE` (default), caches downloaded data current R session avoid repeated downloads.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: tibble columns: country, partyfacts_id, url, name_short, name,   name_native, year_founded, year_dissolved.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: data comes Partyfacts project (<https://partyfacts.org/>), links party datasets provides Wikipedia URLs political parties. data downloaded Partyfacts GitHub repository.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Download the dataset pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia()  # View parties from Germany pf_data[pf_data$country == "DEU", ] } # }

what: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
text: Search Partyfacts Wikipedia dataset party name /country.

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
code: lookup_party_url(party_name, country = NULL, data = NULL, exact = FALSE)

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
text: party_name character string search party names. search case-insensitive matches partial names. country Optional. ISO 3-letter country code (e.g., "DEU", "USA", "GBR") filter results. data Optional. Partyfacts dataset ([get_partyfacts_wikipedia()]). provided, downloads data automatically. exact Logical. `TRUE`, requires exact match party name. Default `FALSE` (partial matching).

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
text: tibble matching parties Wikipedia URLs.

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Search for parties with "Democratic" in the name lookup_party_url("Democratic")  # Search within a specific country lookup_party_url("SPD", country = "DEU")  # Exact match lookup_party_url("CDU", country = "DEU", exact = TRUE) } # }

what: partycoloR: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia — partycoloR-package
title: partycoloR: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia — partycoloR-package
text: Extract political party colors logos English Wikipedia party pages. Provides functions scrape party infoboxes color codes (HEX HTML color names) logo images. Includes integration Partyfacts database easy party lookups. Designed political scientists party researchers working electoral party data.

text: Maintainer: Lukas Warode lukas.warode@gmx.de

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: New function get_party_color() - vectorized color extraction support multiple colors (all_colors parameter) color normalization. New function get_party_logo() - extract party logo URLs Wikipedia pages. New function get_party_info() - extract color logo single call better efficiency. New Partyfacts integration: get_partyfacts_wikipedia() - download Partyfacts Wikipedia dataset lookup_party_url() - search parties name country get_party_color_by_name() - convenience function combining lookup color extraction clear_partycolor_cache() - clear cached Partyfacts data

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: Functions now fully vectorized work seamlessly dplyr::mutate(). Better error handling - invalid URLs return NA instead throwing errors. Color normalization converts named colors (e.g., “red”) hex codes expands 3-digit hex codes 6 digits. Added comprehensive test suite using testthat. Complete vignette examples best practices. Updated use modern tidyverse patterns (replaced gather/spread pivot_longer/pivot_wider).

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: original wikipedia_party_color() function now deprecated. Use get_party_color() instead. package now requires R >= 4.1.0.

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: Added detailed function documentation examples. New vignette: “Getting Started partycoloR”. Updated README feature overview quick start guide.

title: partycoloR 0.1.0
text: Initial release wikipedia_party_color() function. Extract party colors English Wikipedia party pages.
